articles.content:
There√¢s something uniquely thrilling about watching the onscreen adaptation of a book you love. Seeing beloved characters and narratives you√¢ve only imagined in your head come to pixelated life can be awe-inspiring, giving readers entirely new perspectives on beloved stories.
Of course, this process can also be disappointing when the adaptations aren√¢t well-done√¢but either way, book-lovers tend to be intrigued when their favorite stories are transformed into onscreen productions.
From Game of Thrones prequels to gripping mysteries, this year√¢s most anticipated book-to-TV shows list is stacked with favorites for lovers of every genre. Read on to discover 12 book-to-TV adaptations coming out in 2026.
- A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms
- Finding Her Edge
- Bridgerton Season 4
- The Last Thing He Told Me Season 2
- Vladimir
- Outlander
- Scarpetta
- Imperfect Women
- Margo√¢s Got Money Troubles
- Lucky
- Pride and Prejudice
- The Five-Star Weekend
A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms
Release Date: January 18, 2026
The HBO Max series A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms expands the Game of Thrones universe even further, building on the success of fellow prequel House of the Dragon. This latest series is based on three novellas by George R. R. Martin called The Hedge Knight, The Sworn Sword, and The Mystery Knight.
The story follows a squire-turned-hedge knight named Dunk who takes on a young squire of his own named Egg. Together, they wander across Westeros and encounter many variations on its ever-expanding cast of characters and creatures. This story focuses more on the characters and less on sweeping political intrigue, and also proves the Game of Thrones extended universe is definitely here to stay.√Ç
Finding Her Edge
Release Date: January 22, 2026
For anyone looking for more ice-sports-related romance after binge-watching Heated Rivalry√¢or simply wanting to dive into a romantic love triangle√¢Finding Her Edge is an easy pick. This new Netflix series is based on a book of the same name by Jennifer Iacopelli, and it tells the story of a competitive ice skater named Adrianna who starts to catch feelings for her new skating partner. Things get complicated, however, when a former flame reappears on the rink.√Ç
Bridgerton Season 4
Release Date: January 29, 2026 (Part 1) and February 26, 2026 (Part 2)
Bridgerton season 4 follows Benedict Bridgerton, the second-eldest Bridgerton brother, as he pursues a mysterious woman he met at a masquerade ball while also navigating his feelings for the family√¢s scullery maid. This season is based on the third Bridgerton book in Julia Quinn√¢s Bridgerton series, An Offer From a Gentleman, and continues to bring viewers deeper into the Bridgerton universe of Regency-era slang and, of course, steamy romance.
The Last Thing He Told Me Season 2
Release Date: February 20, 2026
The Last Thing He Told Me stars Jennifer Garner as a woman named Hannah who is forced to bond with her stepdaughter after her husband unexpectedly vanishes. The first season was based on the novel The Last Thing He Told Me by Laura Dave, and the second season draws on the sequel, The First Time I Saw Him, which takes place five years after the events of the first book and season. The first season premiered in 2023, and season 2 will also follow Hannah as she continues to unravel the implications of her husband√¢s disappearance, albeit this time with a lot more information.
Vladimir
Release Date: March 5
Vladimir, an adaptation of Julia May Jones√¢s book of the same name, follows an unnamed female professor whose life spirals out of control as she becomes more and more obsessed with a coworker. The show stars Rachel Weisz as the central professor and Leo Woodall as the object of her fixation, and author Jones serves as the writer, creator, and executive producer, so it√¢s sure to be at least a somewhat faithful adaptation.√Ç
Outlander
Release Date: March 6, 2026
Outlander is coming to a close in 2026 with one eighth and final season. The epic series is based on the Outlander book series by Diana Gabaldon, and season 8 will focus on the eighth, ninth, and tenth books in the series√¢Written In My Own Heart√¢s Blood, Go Tell the Bees That I Am Gone, and an unnamed tenth volume.
The series follows a time-traveling nurse named Claire Randall who winds up in 18th century Scotland, where she falls in love with a warrior named Jamie Fraser. The pair travel across time and space and experience countless adventures threaded with fantasy, violence, and passion.
Inevitably, season 8 has a lot to wrap up, though plot details are being kept hidden. "Now, in normal circumstances√¢one book per season√¢they can fit roughly 10% of the book's content into the show. How much of the (VERY roughly speaking) 1,200,000 words of those three books do you think they can get into ten hours of television?" Gabaldon wrote online of season 8√¢s plot. "Obviously, they're going to have to cherry-pick some prime scenes/threads to film, and try to fit them into a framework that makes sense for one season, and that they can bring to a reasonably satisfactory conclusion."
Scarpetta
Release Date: March 11, 2026
Scarpetta is a TV show based on the book series of the same name by Liz Sarnoff. It follows Kay Scarpetta, a forensic pathologist who travels around the world investigating various crimes. The forthcoming Amazon Prime Video series stars Nicole Kidman and Jamie Lee Curtis, who are also producing the show, with Kidman taking the helm as the titular Scarpetta and Curtis playing her older sister, Dorothy.
Imperfect Women
Release Date: March 18, 2026
Elizabeth Moss and Kerry Washington star in this Apple TV+ adaptation of Araminta Hall√¢s book of the same name. Imperfect Women follows a woman named Eleanor whose life implodes when her friend, Nancy, is found dead the very same night the two meet for dinner. Eleanor begins comparing notes about Nancy with her friend Mary, who also knew the deceased, and soon, complicated and disturbing details about the trio√¢s past lives as students at Oxford begin to emerge.√Ç
Margo√¢s Got Money Troubles
Release Date: April 15, 2026
In this upcoming Apple TV+ comedy series, Elle Fanning portrays a young woman named Margo who finds herself in a rough spot after getting pregnant following an affair with her college English professor. Strapped for cash, she turns to OnlyFans, where she begins to unexpectedly achieve massive success. At the same time, she begins reconnecting with her father, a former professional wrestler.√Ç
In addition to Fanning, the cast includes Nicole Kidman as Margo and her professor√¢s mediator, Michelle Pfeiffer as Margo√¢s mother, and Nick Offerman as her father. The TV series is based on the book of the same name by Rufi Thorpe, and it promises to be a blend of contemporary realism and star-studded charisma.
Lucky
Release Date: July 15, 2026
Anya Taylor-Joy takes center stage in this Apple TV+ limited series, which is based on Marissa Stapley√¢s novel of the same name. It follows Taylor-Joy as a con artist named Lucky whose life goes off the rails after a heist goes wrong, leading the FBI to pick up her scent. Its star-studded cast also includes Annette Bening and Timothy Olyphant.

articles.excerpt:

They might be the first animals known to fake a floral scent
A beetle species‚Äô...
articles.content:
These Parasitic Beetles Mimic the Smell of Flowers So They Can Trick Bees and Raid Their Nests, New Research Suggests
They might be the first animals known to fake a floral scent
A beetle species‚Äô larvae seem to bamboozle bees by smelling like flowers. This newly discovered deceptive strategy might be the first known example of an animal imitating floral scents, according to a study posted January 15 on the preprint server bioRxiv. It has not been peer-reviewed
The trickery works like this: Larvae of the European black oil beetle (Meloe proscarabaeus) ascend grasses and cluster together, taking on the appearance of orange flowers, and produce floral-smelling compounds. When a fooled bee approaches them, the larvae latch onto the pollinator and ride back to its nest‚Äîwhere they feast on bee eggs.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a beautiful study,‚Äù says Consuelo De Moraes, a chemical ecologist at ETH Z√ºrich who was not involved in the work, to Erik Stokstad at Science. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing to me how sophisticated these interactions are.‚Äù
Parasitic beetles use a range of tricks to lure bees. For example, one species emits female bee sex pheromones to attract a specific type of male bee, while another species perches atop flowers and waits for pollinators to gather nectar. But European black oil beetle larvae were known to form strange clumps and chow down on a wide variety of hosts, leading the researchers behind the new work to hypothesize that the insects employ a unique strategy.
So, the team collected adult European black oil beetles in Germany in the spring of 2024 and 2025 and kept them in greenhouse tanks until they mated. The females laid thousands of eggs that hatched a few weeks later. Then, the larvae climbed up grass stems, and the researchers gathered the young creatures for chemical analysis.
The work revealed that the larvae emit 17 compounds that are often found in flowers but are rare in insects. These include linalool oxide and lilac aldehyde, which are known to draw in pollinators. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt just that [the beetles] were producing one compound and then loosely trying to mimic a flower,‚Äù says study co-author Ryan Alam, a synthetic chemist at the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology in Germany, to Richard Kemeny at Science News. ‚ÄúIt was like their own personal larval perfume.‚Äù
Did you know? Plants play tricks too
Animals are far from the only deceptive organisms. Many plants also trick creatures into doing their bidding. For instance, the black-bulb yam seems to produce plump, fake berries to trick birds into spreading its offspring, according to a recent study.
Then, Alam and his colleagues made their own blends of larvae-emitted scents to see how bees would respond. The four tested bee species preferred synthetic beetle perfume to wheatgrass, which was used as a control.
The compounds also attracted the larvae, the team found, which suggests that the odor might tell the young ones to gather atop plant stems in early spring, before most flowers bloom. This, the authors note in the study, points to an ‚Äúintriguing evolutionary scenario‚Äù where the larvae may have once been drawn to flowers and then evolved to produce a strong scent themselves, cutting out the need for the natural floral signal.
May Berenbaum, an entomologist at the University of Illinois Urbana‚ÄìChampaign who was not involved in the study, tells Science that researchers probably find chemical forms of deception less often than visual forms because humans see better than they smell. But, she adds, more examples will likely emerge with dedicated efforts.
‚ÄúIt takes really careful observation and intuition to figure out some of these very strange relationships,‚Äù Berenbaum says.

articles.content:
Physicists Create Homemade Cosmic Dust, Which Could Help Them Figure Out How the Building Blocks of Life First Reached Earth
Cosmic dust normally comes from dying stars. The recipe for a lab-made version includes a few gases, vacuum tubes and electricity
Tiny specks of rock, ice, minerals or other chemical compounds float freely throughout the universe. This so-called cosmic dust contains ingredients crucial to the formation of stars, planets, comets and even people.
Now, using gases and electricity to mimic the harsh environment of space, physicists have concocted their own lab-made version of cosmic dust. The work, described in a study published January 30 in the Astrophysical Journal, could help researchers investigate how elements crucial for life reached Earth, and simulate how life might pop up elsewhere in the cosmos.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like we have recreated a little bit of the universe in a bottle in our lab,‚Äù says study co-author Linda Losurdo, a physicist at the University of Sydney in Australia, in a statement.
Researchers suspect that cosmic dust comes from dying stars. A giant one near the end of its life will grow very hot around its exterior, begin to break apart and ‚Äúbelch out ‚Ä¶ huge waves of carbon,‚Äù Losurdo tells the Guardian‚Äôs Donna Lu. It also expels hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen, and all the elements get bombarded by high-energy particles. This creates chemical reactions and results in what are called CHON molecules, which play key roles in the foundations of life.
Did you know? Stars create elements
These huge balls of gas are element factories. Massive stars convert lighter elements, such as helium and carbon, into heavier ones, like neon, magnesium and iron, via nuclear fusion. They release the elements when they explode in bright supernovas.
The stuff burped up by stars is ‚Äúquite similar‚Äù to the materials found in meteorites, Losurdo tells the Guardian. Researchers often rely on these space rocks to study CHON molecules and answer questions such as how these molecules got to Earth. Some hypotheses include that they formed on the planet during its youth, were dropped off later by comets and meteorites, came during the solar system‚Äôs birth about 4.6 billion years ago or originated from some combination of the three.
But meteorites are rare commodities, as most that fall to Earth burn up in the planet‚Äôs atmosphere before reaching the surface.
So, Losurdo and David McKenzie, also a physicist at the University of Sydney, added nitrogen, carbon dioxide and acetylene, a gas with carbon and hydrogen, to tubes with air vacuumed out, mimicking outer space. Then, they blasted the gases with 10,000 volts of electrical potential for roughly an hour, creating plasma.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre completing a circuit across the gas itself, so the gas is getting excited, electrons are flying off, creating an environment in which things want to bind and coalesce and aggregate,‚Äù Losurdo tells CNN‚Äôs Jacopo Prisco. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs a very natural process. It‚Äôs something that we know for certain happens around stars.‚Äù
The energy sparked chemical reactions that created new compounds, including cosmic dust, which fell onto silicon wafers inside the tubes. Further analysis revealed that the lab-made dust emitted infrared light signatures similar to space-made dust, as previously detected by telescopes.
The new research is ‚Äúa really beautiful method‚Äù that creates a substance similar to ‚Äúwhat we think interstellar dust is like,‚Äù Sara Webb, an astrophysicist at Swinburne University in Australia who was not involved in the study, tells the Guardian.
‚ÄúOne very exciting possibility, which is probably further down the track, is ‚Ä¶ to use this kind of simulated cosmic dust in other organic chemistry experiments, to simulate early life formation on different types of planets,‚Äù she adds.
Damanveer Grewal, a cosmochemist at Yale University who was not involved in the study, tells CNN in an email that the new work bridges an important gap between telescopic observations and laboratory analysis.
It can also be used as a jumping-off point to test ideas about the origins of organics in space, he notes. ‚ÄúThe findings suggest that complex organic matter forms readily in stellar environments and is not unique to our solar system,‚Äù Grewal says. ‚ÄúIf these materials are widespread, it implies that the essential chemical building blocks for life are likely available to planetary systems throughout the galaxy.‚Äù

articles.title: Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
articles.author: Reda√ß√£o
articles.excerpt:
Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
A new analysis of the Hever Rose portrait...
articles.content:
Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
A new analysis of the Hever Rose portrait suggests that the painter deliberately modified an existing template to showcase Anne‚Äôs hands‚Äîwith no extra digits‚Äîholding a delicate rose
In 1585, a Catholic priest living in exile published an unflattering description of Anne Boleyn, the mother of England‚Äôs reigning Protestant queen, Elizabeth I.
Anne, who‚Äôd been executed on charges of treason in 1536, had ‚Äúan oval face of a sallowish complexion, as if troubled with jaundice,‚Äù the priest wrote. ‚ÄúShe had a projecting tooth under the upper lip, and on her right hand six fingers.‚Äù
This purported extra finger‚Äîa characteristic sometimes associated with witchcraft during the early modern era‚Äîprovided fuel for Elizabeth‚Äôs critics, who viewed her claim to the English throne as tenuous. (She‚Äôd been declared a bastard following her mother‚Äôs execution.)
Drawing on now-debunked accounts of Anne‚Äôs physical appearance, Catholics accused her of witchcraft, heresy and scandalous conduct, engaging in a ‚Äúwidespread and vicious‚Äù assassination of her character, writes historian Tracy Borman in Anne Boleyn and Elizabeth I: The Mother and Daughter Who Forever Changed British History. That negative reputation persisted for centuries.
Now, new research conducted for an exhibition at Anne‚Äôs childhood home, Hever Castle in Kent, England, reveals an early effort to rehabilitate the Tudor queen‚Äôs image. As Dalya Alberge reports for the Guardian, infrared analysis of the late 16th-century Hever Rose portrait of Anne shows that its creator deliberately reworked an existing template to show both of her hands.
‚ÄúBy clearly displaying five digits on each hand, the portrait acts as a visual rebuttal to hostile rumors and as a defense of Anne Boleyn‚Äîand, by extension, of her daughter Elizabeth‚Äôs legitimacy,‚Äù says Owen Emmerson, an assistant curator at Hever Castle, in a statement.
Did you know? Anne Boleyn and witchcraft
- Contrary to popular belief, witchcraft wasn‚Äôt one of the charges leveled against Anne during her trial. Instead, the second wife of Henry VIII faced contrived accusations of adultery, incest and conspiring to kill the king.
- In a 2023 journal article, historian Sylvia Barbara Soberton addressed many of the misconceptions surrounding the Tudor queen and witchcraft. She argued that Nicholas Sander, the Catholic priest who wrote the disparaging description of Anne, never actually described her as a witch, instead criticizing her for the crime of heresy. His words were later misconstrued due to an inaccurate translation.
- At the same time, Soberton pointed out that rumors of Anne practicing witchcraft circulated both during her lifetime and in the decades following her execution.
During the Tudor era, which lasted from 1485 to 1603, artists often based their likenesses of royals on preapproved templates or ‚Äúface patterns‚Äù instead of painting from life. This practice‚Äîwhich proved particularly popular during Elizabeth‚Äôs nearly 45-year reign‚Äîhelped monarchs assert control over their public personas and avoid the time-consuming process of sitting for portraits in person.
The Hever Rose portrait is based on a template known as the ‚ÄúB‚Äù pattern, which is perhaps best exemplified by an iconic image of Anne housed at the National Portrait Gallery in London. In this pattern, Anne is typically portrayed from the bust up, with a pearl ‚ÄúB‚Äù necklace around her neck and her hands out of view. Infrared reflectography scans taken at the Hamilton Kerr Institute at the University of Cambridge capture the moment when the Hever Rose artist decided to deviate from this established template by featuring Anne‚Äôs hands, which are shown clasping a rose.
‚ÄúThis preliminary design was laid down with confident, continuous lines, indicating that it was transferred from a pre-existing pattern rather than drawn freehand,‚Äù Emmerson tells the Daily Mail‚Äôs Wiliam Hunter. ‚ÄúAt a later stage, however, the artist altered this plan. Anne‚Äôs hands were added in, cutting across the earlier design.‚Äù
In addition to analyzing the infrared scans, the Hever team performed a dendrochronology assessment of the portrait, dating the oak panel on which it was painted to around 1583. At the time, Elizabeth‚Äôs ‚Äúlegitimacy, succession and ancestry were under renewed pressure,‚Äù Emmerson told Smithsonian magazine earlier this year, and rumors about her mother‚Äôs supposed misdeeds ran rampant.
The pope had excommunicated Elizabeth in 1570, giving her Catholic subjects and fellow monarchs license to overthrow her. This situation was ‚Äúcompounded by the fact that she‚Äôs no longer of child-bearing age, she‚Äôs unmarried ‚Ä¶ so she cannot look to the future to promote her legitimacy,‚Äù Emmerson told the Independent‚Äôs Harry Cockburn last month. Critics of the Protestant queen looked to her Catholic cousin Mary, Queen of Scots, as a viable claimant to the English throne.
Given the timeframe of the Hever Rose portrait‚Äôs creation, Emmerson and exhibition co-curator Kate McCaffrey argue that ‚Äúthe artist was directed to alter the established pattern specifically to show Anne‚Äôs hands, carefully and unmistakably,‚Äù per the statement. Although McCaffrey tells the Guardian that ‚Äúit‚Äôs impossible to say‚Äù whether Elizabeth herself commissioned this portrait, she believes that it‚Äôs ‚Äútoo much of a coincidence for it not to be in response to rumors.‚Äù
McCaffrey adds, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Elizabeth‚Äôs way of not only reclaiming her own legitimacy and lineage but also restoring the legitimacy of her mother.‚Äù
Historian Helene Harrison first observed the potential connection between the Hever Rose portrait and the Catholic priest‚Äôs claims in her 2025 book, The Many Faces of Anne Boleyn: Interpreting Image and Perception. As Harrison writes in a blog post, ‚ÄúAnne‚Äôs [hands] seem deliberately splayed, almost as a message.‚Äù
The Hever Rose news isn‚Äôt the only explosive revelation shared in recent weeks by the castle‚Äôs curators. In January, Emmerson announced the results of a technical analysis performed by Lawrence Hendra, an art historian at Philip Mould & Company, who identified four paintings‚Äîportraits of Anne and Elizabeth, as well as Elizabeth‚Äôs half-sister, Mary I, and her paternal great-grandfather, Edward IV‚Äîas the work of the same artist. The four sitters share ‚Äúthe same underlying facial geometry,‚Äù despite the fact that they weren‚Äôt all genetically related, Emmerson told Smithsonian. (Anne was linked to Mary and Edward through her marriage to Elizabeth‚Äôs father, Henry VIII.)
As Emmerson explained to the London Times‚Äô Richard Brooks last month, the artist may have used the same facial template for each of the four portraits, cutting and pasting Elizabeth‚Äôs face onto those of her predecessors ‚Äúto show a legitimate and God-ordained line of succession.‚Äù
Viewed together, the new analyses testify to a time of crisis during Elizabeth‚Äôs reign. Besieged by threats to her throne‚Äîincluding multiple plots to replace her with Mary, Queen of Scots‚ÄîElizabeth looked to portraiture as a powerful propaganda tool to spread messages emphasizing her resemblance to past monarchs and subtly disavowing falsehoods about her mother.
Overall, the Hever Castle exhibition seeks to move past the many myths surrounding Anne by bringing together more than 30 likenesses of her.
‚ÄúVery few portraits of Anne Boleyn have undergone this level of scientific study,‚Äù says Emmerson in the statement. ‚ÄúBy combining technical analysis with historical context, this exhibition brings us closer to seeing Anne as her contemporaries might have done‚Äînot as a myth, but as a real woman.‚Äù
‚ÄúCapturing a Queen: The Image of Anne Boleyn‚Äù will be on view at Hever Castle & Gardens in Hever, England, from February 11, 2026, to January 2, 2027.

articles.content:
This Carved, Painted Zapotec Tomb Is Mexico‚Äôs Most Important Archaeological Discovery in a Decade
The tomb features the carvings of a huge owl head and at least three probable ancestors
Archaeologists in Mexico have uncovered an incredibly well-preserved Zapotec tomb dating back to the early seventh century. The tomb boasts intricately carved walls, murals and sculptures‚Äîincluding a massive owl, a Zapotec symbol of night and death.
It‚Äôs the ‚Äúmost significant archaeological discovery in a decade in Mexico,‚Äù said Mexico‚Äôs president, Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo, at a January press conference, per Live Science‚Äôs Kristina Killgrove.
Researchers unearthed the tomb in the valleys of central Oaxaca, a state in southern Mexico, according to a translated statement from Mexico‚Äôs National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH). Officials were clued into the tomb‚Äôs location by an anonymous report of looting at the site, per Live Science. Oaxaca is the native land of the Zapotecs‚Äîalso called the ‚ÄúCloud People‚Äù‚Äîa pre-Hispanic population who have lived among its highlands and valleys since the sixth century B.C.E.
The entrance of the stone tomb‚Äôs antechamber, its small front room, is decorated with a complex sculpted portrait. A large owl head protrudes from the overdoor, its curved beak open, and inside its mouth is the sculpted, painted face of a man wearing wide hoop earrings. Per the statement, the man was likely a Zapotec lord‚Äîperhaps the ancestor to whom the tomb was dedicated.
The entrance is flanked by intricately carved, painted door jambs, one depicting a woman and the other a man. Each figure holds artifacts and wears a cloak, skirt and large headdress. According to a video from INAH, these full-length portraits may depict other ancestors buried in the tomb. But they could also represent the tomb‚Äôs guardians, per the statement.
Inside the antechamber is another doorway, leading into the burial chamber. Above this doorway is a frieze of engraved tombstones carved with ‚Äúcalendrical names,‚Äù per the statement. The ancient Zapotec calendar, composed of 260 days divided into 20 months, represented days through animals and other natural images. The people used the calendar to name gods and important people: Each was identified by a specific symbol associated with their birth date, reports Live Science.
The walls of the burial chamber are covered in murals. Painted in ochre, white, red, green and blue, the murals depict a parade of people walking toward the entrance of the tomb. The people carry bags of copal, resin from tropical trees that Mesoamericans‚Äîincluding Zapotecs, Maya and Aztecs‚Äîcommonly burned during ceremonies.
Ancient Zapotec tombs are reputed for their intricate construction and decoration. In 2023, five 2,000-year-old Zapotec tombs were unearthed in Oaxaca. One of them was composed of multiple chambers arranged in a cross-shape, and it was decorated with red and yellow murals depicting warfare.
Quick facts: The tombs at Monte Alb√°n
- Also in Oaxaca is Monte Alb√°n, which was the capital of Zapotec society between about 500 B.C.E. and 850 C.E.
- Monte Alb√°n‚Äôs sprawling ruins include plazas, pyramids, a ball court, tunnels and likely hundreds of tombs. These elaborate ancient funerary chambers are spacious, vibrantly painted and filled with riches.
Researchers are conserving, studying and protecting the recently discovered tomb, per the statement. This includes stabilizing the mural paints, which are vulnerable to degradation from roots, insects and environment changes. To learn more about the Zapotec rituals and funerary practices associated with the tomb, researchers are analyzing its inscriptions, ceramics and iconography.
Claudia Curiel de Icaza, Mexico‚Äôs secretary of culture, said at the press conference that the tomb is an ‚Äúexceptional discovery‚Äù for what it says about Zapotec culture and ‚Äúits social organization, funeral rituals and belief system, preserved by the architecture and the murals,‚Äù per CNN‚Äôs Jack Guy.
Curiel de Icaza recently visited the tomb, alongside local residents, INAH researchers and the governor of Oaxaca, report La Jornada‚Äôs Ana M√≥nica Rodr√≠guez and Jorge A. P√©rez. Before entering the chambers, Curiel de Icaza blessed its entrance by pouring a shot of mezcal on the floor.
One INAH researcher paused at the entrance, realizing they would be entering a tomb that doesn‚Äôt belong to them, La Jornada reports. The researcher raised their hands and asked permission of the wind, earth and Zapotecs to enter.

articles.author: Reda√ß√£o
articles.excerpt:
A Smithsonian magazine special report
The National Gallery of Art Acquires 17th-Century Masterpiece by Baroque Painter Artemisia Gentileschi
‚ÄúMary Magdalene in Ecstasy‚Äù is the gallery‚Äôs first work by...
articles.content:
A Smithsonian magazine special report
The National Gallery of Art Acquires 17th-Century Masterpiece by Baroque Painter Artemisia Gentileschi
‚ÄúMary Magdalene in Ecstasy‚Äù is the gallery‚Äôs first work by the Italian artist, who was one of the most influential female painters of her time
The National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. has announced the acquisition of a rare painting by the Baroque artist Artemisia Gentileschi, the 17th century‚Äôs most influential female painter.
Mary Magdalene in Ecstasy, painted circa 1625, will be on view beginning later this month. It‚Äôs the gallery‚Äôs first painting by the Italian artist, and art historians consider it to be one of her finest works.
‚ÄúIt is a momentous occasion to bring Mary Magdalene in Ecstasy into the National Gallery‚Äôs collection as our first notable example of Artemisia Gentileschi‚Äôs remarkable work,‚Äù Kaywin Feldman, the gallery‚Äôs director, says in a statement. ‚ÄúThis acquisition marks a major addition to our historical holdings, reflecting our continued commitment to deepening our collection, and in turn, expanding public access to great works of art.‚Äù
Quick fact: Artemisia Gentileschi‚Äôs trailblazing career
In 1616, when the artist was in her 20s, she became the first woman to be admitted to Florence‚Äôs Academy of the Arts of Drawing.
Throughout history, other paintings of Mary Magdalene were ‚Äúlargely portrayals of death and penitence,‚Äù often placing her ‚Äúalone in a setting which is unplaceable, nondescript,‚Äù wrote the Cleveland Review of Books‚Äô Kameryn Alexa Carter in 2023. In Gentileschi‚Äôs interpretation, the illuminated saint bares more skin than usual and appears in a moment of passion. However, in the 17th century, these states weren‚Äôt seen as mutually exclusive.
‚ÄúThat binary that we now use between the spiritual and the erotic was actually then closer, and entwined in a way that is very hard for us to understand,‚Äù Eve Straussman-Pflanzer, the museum‚Äôs curator and head of Italian and Spanish paintings, tells the Art Newspaper‚Äôs J.S. Marcus.
A skull, cross and ointment jar‚Äîitems that she‚Äôs usually associated with‚Äîare notably absent. Instead, the viewer is drawn to focus solely on Magdalene‚Äôs expressions.
The painting has striking similarities to a work by the same name painted by Caravaggio in 1606. Caravaggio had worked closely with Gentileschi‚Äôs father, and his style profoundly influenced her work.
Completed just two decades apart from each other, Gentileschi and Caravaggio‚Äôs Magdalene paintings have followed a strikingly similar path over the past 400 years. Both vanished from the public record and were assumed to be lost to history before they were ultimately rediscovered.
Caravaggio‚Äôs piece emerged in 2014, while Gentileschi‚Äôs was discovered in the south of France in 2011. The latter was subsequently sold for $1.1 million in a 2014 auction‚Äîseveral times the estimated price.
Widespread recognition of Gentileschi‚Äôs talent and influence on Baroque art is a relatively recent development.
‚ÄúFemale painters were always there but slipped from history along the way, mostly in the 19th century,‚Äù Andrea Rygg Karberg, director of the Nivaagaard Collection in Denmark, told the Sunday Times‚Äô Julia Buckley in September 2025. ‚ÄúWe lost half of history. Sofonisba [Anguissola] and Artemisia were really famous in their own time, but they were only rediscovered in the 1970s.‚Äù
The Nivaagaard, a small gallery on Denmark‚Äôs eastern coast, made history last fall by becoming a world leader in Renaissance and Baroque-era paintings by female artists after outbidding a group of international museums to acquire Susanna and the Elders, another painting by Gentileschi, for an undisclosed sum.
Earlier this week, one of five known self-portraits by Gentileschi‚Äîand likely the earliest, painted when the artist was nearly 20‚Äîsold at a Christie‚Äôs auction for a record $5.69 million, per Artnet‚Äôs Eileen Kinsella. The portrait depicts the painter dressed as St. Catherine of Alexandria, and it has been requested for an exhibition at the Nivaagaard beginning in 2028.
After experts conduct a technical analysis of its pigments, Mary Magdalene in Ecstasy will be placed within a 17th-century frame and exhibited on the main floor of the gallery‚Äôs West Building.

articles.author: Reda√ß√£o
articles.excerpt: Shoes are everywhere, yet most people never think about how they are made. In the Dutch town of Waalwijk, where the Dutch shoe and leather industry originates, the Schoenenkwartier slows that process down and shows what usually stays out of sight. Inside, the shoe-making process is laid out step by
